data.head: Why death certification is important
data.body:
This application guides doctors in filling out Death certificates.

Death certification forms an important part of a doctor’s duties because the information recorded in death certificates helps decision makers determine health priorities for prevention of deaths because of similar causes in the future.

data.head: Identification data in death certificate
data.body:
This information is of critical importance to correctly identifying the deceased for both legal and statistical purposes.

The details vary from country to country but are likely to include; date and place of death, full name and place of residence, sex and race/ethnicity age profession or occupation.

data.head: Cause of death is defined as,
data.body: All those diseases, morbid conditions or injuries which either resulted in or contributed to death and the circumstance of the accident or violence which produced any such injuries.

data.head: The underlying cause of death is,
data.body: the disease or injury which initiated the train of morbid events leading directly to death, or the circumstances of the accident or violence which produced the fatal injury.

Page3.section1: International Form of Medical Certificate of Cause of Death (known as the death certificate) is recommended by the World Health Organization for certification of death in all countries.
Page3.section2: The international form has two main sections

FrameA.head: The frame A of the death certificate is divided into three sections
sections: Part 1 : Report sequence / chain of events leading to death
Part 2 : Other significant conditions contributing to death
A column to record the approximate interval between onset of the condition and death

FrameASection1.Head: Part 1 : Report sequence/chain of events leading to death
HowToFill: Part 1 of the certificate is where you write the chain of events leading to death, starting from the immediate or direct cause.
There are four lines in part 1.
Start at line 1(a), with the immediate (direct) cause.
If the direct cause reported on line 1a, was due to another disease or condition, this cause should be entered in line 1b.
If there are more events leading to death, they are recorded in lines 1c or 1d.
The underlying cause is recorded in the lowest used line.
Enter only one disease or condition per line
Do not record the mode of dying, such as cardiac arrest, respiratory failure or heart failure.

FrameASection2.Head: Part 2 : Other significant conditions contributing to death
HowToFill: Part 2 of the death certificate records all other significant or contributory diseases or conditions that were present at the time of death but did not directly lead to the underlying cause of death listed in Part 1.

FrameASection3.Head: A column to record the approximate interval between onset of the condition and death
HowToFill: The column on the right-hand side of the death certificate is for recording the approximate time interval between onset of the condition and death.
The time interval should be written for all conditions.
Time periods can be minutes, hours, days, weeks, months or years.

FrameB.head: The frame B of the death certificate is divided into four sections
sections: Place of occurrence of the external cause
For women, was the deceased pregnant?

data.body: The manner of death section was added to the death certificate by public health officials to assist in clarifying the circumstances of death and how an injury was sustained—not as a legally binding opinion—and with a major goal of assisting coders who code and classify cause-of-death information from death certificates for statistical purposes.
Manner of death categories, Disease, Accident, Intentional self-harm and Assault are very straight forward and the meaning is clear to the physician.

data.head: Could not be determined
data.body:
Includes:
When available information is insufficient to enable a medical or legal authority to make a distinction between unintentional, self-harm and assault.  It includes self-inflicted injuries, but not poisoning, when not specified whether as unintentional or intentional.

Excludes:
Cases where investigation is PENDING or the manner of death is UNKNOWN to the certifier at the time of certification.

data.head: War
data.body:
Includes:
Injuries to military personnel and civilians caused by war and civil insurrection

data.head: Pending (Investigation)
data.body:
Includes:
When certification of cause of death and/or manner of death is incomplete because an investigation is pending.

Excludes:
When an investigation has been completed and the manner of death COULD NOT BE DETERMINED

data.head: Unknown
data.body:
Includes:
When the manner of death is unknown to the certifier at the time of reporting

Excludes:
Deaths PENDING (INVESTIGATION) and when an investigation has been completed and the manner of death COULD NOT BE DETERMINED
The certifier must record the accurate place of occurrence of the accident, violence or poisoning.

data: Check the accuracy of identification data including correct spelling of the names
Document only one condition per line
Check the Document on clear sequence of events leading to death
Do not enter ill-defined conditions as underlying cause of death
Do not make alterations or erasures
If you want to delete an entry, draw a single line across it

Case1.CaseDescription:
A 50-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital vomiting blood for two days and was diagnosed as having bleeding oesophageal varices.

Six months ago, she was diagnosed as having liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension.

The woman had a four-year history of hepatitis B infection. Three days later, she died.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death

Case2.CaseDescription:
A man dies of cerebral haemorrhage, three-days after it’s onset.

This resulted from secondary hypertension which he had for last one year.

Hypertension was secondary to chronic pyelonephritis which he had for last two years.

The chronic pyelonephritis was a result of outflow obstruction, due to benign prostatic hyperplasia that he was having for last five years.

He also had a history of diabetes mellitus, which had been diagnosed ten years before his death.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death

CaseExercises.Description:
A male aged 49 years was admitted to hospital with a history of fever, disorientation and drowsiness for the last 2 days.

Focal neurological findings were identified on physical examination and a provisional diagnosis of meningitis was made.

A diagnostic lumber puncture was performed for CSF examination.

Staphylococcus aureus organism was isolated from CSF and the provisional diagnosis was confirmed as Staphylococcus aureus meningitis.

Despite IV antibiotic administration his condition worsened and on 3rd of admission blood cultures were also positive for Staphylococcus aureus and the patient expired on 4th day of admission due to septic shock.

He was a diagnosed case of type II diabetes for the last 10 years and has had a renal transplant 6 years back.

A male aged 64 years admitted to hospital with an arteriosclerotic cerebral infarction.

He was transferred to rehabilitation two months later where he developed hypostatic pneumonia.

In ICU sputum cultured Klebsiella pneumoniae and the patient died 2 days after admission to the ICU.

He was also addicted to alcohol for the past 20 years and on regular medication for Ischaemic heart disease for the last 10 years.

SpecialCases.Title: Diabetes Mellitus
SpecialCases.CaseDescription:
Diabetes mellitus can be the underlying cause of death, or a risk factor for another underlying cause of death.

 As a rule, if the patient dies from a complication of diabetes mellitus(e.g. diabetic nephropathy) document diabetes mellitus (type I or II) as the underlying cause of death.

If a patient dies from stroke or acute myocardial infarction, document diabetes in Part 2 as a risk factor (other significant condition).
SpecialCases.CaseExample:
A 75-year-old female had a 15-year history of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), a 13-year history of mild hypertension treated with thiazide diuretics, and an uncomplicated myocardial infarction 6 years prior to the present illness.

She was found disoriented in her apartment and brought to the hospital.

On admission she was noted to be unresponsive, without focal neurologic signs, and severely dehydrated with a blood pressure of 90/60.

Initial laboratory tests disclosed severe hyperglycaemia, hyper osmolarity, azotaemia, and mild ketosis without acidosis.

A diagnosis of hyperosmolar non - ketotic coma was made.

The patient was vigorously treated with fluids, electrolytes, insulin, and broad-spectrum antibiotics, although no source for infection was documented.

Within 72 hours, the patient’s hyperosmolar, hyperglycaemic state was resolved. However, she remained anuric with progressive azotaemia.

Attempts at renal dialysis were unsuccessful, and the patient died on the 8th hospital day in severe acute renal failure.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death

SpecialCases.Title: Accident, violence and other external causes
SpecialCases.CaseDescription: When death occurs as a consequence of injury or violence, the external cause (the circumstance of the injury) should always be listed as the underlying cause.
SpecialCases.CaseExample:
A 45-year-old electrician fall from a lamp post while attending to repair job in a factory.

He was admitted to the hospital. An X ray skull done upon admission revealed fractured temporal bone.

CT scan head conducted three-hours after admission showed evidence of sub Dural haematoma.

Twelve hours after the admission, he died of cerebral compression due to subdural haematoma.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death

SpecialCases.Title: Pregnancy and childbirth
SpecialCases.CaseDescription: If a woman dies during pregnancy or within 42 days of the termination of a pregnancy, the fact that the woman was pregnant should be indicated on the certificate, even if the direct cause of death is not related to the pregnancy or to childbirth.
SpecialCases.CaseExample:
A female aged 24 years, pregnant for 4 months, was admitted to hospital with sudden onset of hemiplegia.

Her history revealed that she had suffered from rheumatic fever at the age of 10 years, and a diagnosis of mitral stenosis was made.

Furthermore, a CT scan of the brain identified a cerebral embolus and on her second day in hospital the patient died.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death

SpecialCases.Title: Pregnancy and childbirth - II
SpecialCases.CaseDescription: If a woman dies during pregnancy or within 42 days of the termination of a pregnancy, the fact that the woman was pregnant should be indicated on the certificate, even if the direct cause of death is not related to the pregnancy or to childbirth.
SpecialCases.CaseExample:
A 24-year-old woman was admitted with severe right sided abdominal pain of 6 hours duration.

She collapsed and was resuscitated in the emergency department.

The history revealed that she had amenorrhoea for 11 weeks.

Ultrasound scan confirmed the clinical suspicion of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy and she was prepared for surgery.

But before the surgery she died of hypovolaemic shock after 2 hours of admission.

CaseApplication.Heading: Sequence of events leading to death
